pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [5573c0a41d](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20021/commits/5573c0a41d5f4b716c5bd0e88a1c90c0208a18a3)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.RestrictedProduct` (new file)|1012|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ RestrictedProduct`
`+ continuousSMul`
`+ continuous_coe`
`+ continuous_dom`
`+ continuous_dom_prod`
`+ continuous_dom_prod_left`
`+ continuous_dom_prod_right`
`+ continuous_inclusion`
`+ continuous_rng_of_bot`

`+ exists_structureMap_eq_of_forall`
`+ homeoBot`
`+ homeoTop`
`+ inclusion`
`+ inclusion_eq_id`
`+ instance : DFunLike (Œ† ≥ i, [R i, A i]_[ùìï]) Œπ R`
`+ instance [hAopen : Fact (‚àÄ i, IsOpen (A i))] [‚àÄ i, WeaklyLocallyCompactSpace (R i)]`
`+ instance [Œ† i, AddGroup (R i)] [‚àÄ i, AddSubgroupClass (S i) (R i)] :`
`+ instance [Œ† i, AddMonoidWithOne (R i)] [‚àÄ i, AddSubmonoidWithOneClass (S i) (R i)] :`
`+ instance [Œ† i, Group (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SubgroupClass (S i) (R i)] :`
`+ instance [Œ† i, Group (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SubgroupClass (S i) (R i)] [‚àÄ i, IsTopologicalGroup (R i)]`
`+ instance [Œ† i, Group (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SubgroupClass (S i) (R i)] [‚àÄ i, IsTopologicalGroup (R i)] :`
`+ instance [Œ† i, Inv (R i)] [‚àÄ i, InvMemClass (S i) (R i)] : Inv (Œ† ≥ i, [R i, B i]_[ùìï])`
`+ instance [Œ† i, Inv (R i)] [‚àÄ i, InvMemClass (S i) (R i)] [‚àÄ i, ContinuousInv (R i)] :`
`+ instance [Œ† i, Monoid (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SubmonoidClass (S i) (R i)] :`
`+ instance [Œ† i, Mul (R i)] [‚àÄ i, MulMemClass (S i) (R i)] : Mul (Œ† ≥ i, [R i, B i]_[ùìï])`
`+ instance [Œ† i, One (R i)] [‚àÄ i, OneMemClass (S i) (R i)] : One (Œ† ≥ i, [R i, B i]_[ùìï])`
`+ instance [Œ† i, Ring (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SubringClass (S i) (R i)] [‚àÄ i, IsTopologicalRing (R i)] :`
`+ instance [‚àÄ i, T0Space (R i)] : T0Space (Œ† ≥ i, [R i, A i]_[ùìï])`
`+ instance [‚àÄ i, T1Space (R i)] : T1Space (Œ† ≥ i, [R i, A i]_[ùìï])`
`+ instance [‚àÄ i, T2Space (R i)] : T2Space (Œ† ≥ i, [R i, A i]_[ùìï])`
`+ instance [‚àÄ i, WeaklyLocallyCompactSpace (R i)] [hS : Fact (cofinite ‚â§ ùìü S)]`
`+ instance {G : Type*} [TopologicalSpace G] [Œ† i, SMul G (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SMulMemClass (S i) G (R i)]`
`+ instance {G : Type*} [Œ† i, SMul G (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SMulMemClass (S i) G (R i)]`
`+ instance {G : Type*} [Œ† i, SMul G (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SMulMemClass (S i) G (R i)] :`
`+ isEmbedding_coe_of_bot`
`+ isEmbedding_coe_of_principal`
`+ isEmbedding_coe_of_top`
`+ isEmbedding_inclusion_principal`
`+ isEmbedding_inclusion_top`
`+ isEmbedding_structureMap`
`+ isOpenEmbedding_inclusion_principal`
`+ isOpenEmbedding_structureMap`
`+ isOpen_forall_imp_mem`
`+ isOpen_forall_imp_mem_of_principal`
`+ isOpen_forall_mem`
`+ isOpen_forall_mem_of_principal`
`+ isTopologicalGroup`
`+ isTopologicalRing`
`+ limit`
`+ locallyCompactSpace_of_group`
`+ nhds_eq_map_inclusion`
`+ nhds_eq_map_structureMap`
`+ nhds_zero_eq_map_ofPre`
`+ nhds_zero_eq_map_structureMap`
`+ range_coe`
`+ range_coe_principal`
`+ range_inclusion`
`+ range_structureMap`
`+ structureMap`
`+ topologicalSpace`
`+ topologicalSpace_eq_iSup`
`+ topologicalSpace_eq_of_bot`
`+ topologicalSpace_eq_of_principal`
`+ topologicalSpace_eq_of_top`
`+ weaklyLocallyCompactSpace_of_cofinite`
`+ weaklyLocallyCompactSpace_of_principal`
`++ instance [Œ† i, DivInvMonoid (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SubgroupClass (S i) (R i)] :`
`++ instance [Œ† i, Mul (R i)] [‚àÄ i, MulMemClass (S i) (R i)] [‚àÄ i, ContinuousMul (R i)] :`
`++ instance [Œ† i, Ring (R i)] [‚àÄ i, SubringClass (S i) (R i)] :`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Regarding the TODOs: the idea I have in mind when I leave these TODOs in the middle of the code is "I know there should be a cleaner way to do this, and if someone struggles upon it and feels inspired to do it it would be nice for the library". But I certainly don't mean either of "these need to be done in order to move forward" and "this is an ugly workaround, fix as soon as possible".

Do we have anything tracking concretely the technical debt? Because I definitely don't think these count as such. Should I just remove the word "TODO"?

Apparently TODOs are fine. Thanks a lot for this very elegant PR!

bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13903645900/job/38901286924)

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13905888022/job/38908712995)

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/13907062026/job/38912495310)

This seems to be failing:
```
error: ././././Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/RestrictedProduct.lean:758:2: failed to synthesize
  LocallyCompactSpace Œ† ≥ (i : Œπ), [R i, ‚Üë(B i)]
```

bors r-
bors d+

:v: ADedecker can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
Canceled.

This is an extremely elegant approach! I left a bunch of nits. I think that generally adding TODOs in the middle of files is discouraged -- are you going to do them, or move them to the top of the file, or just leave them as they are (and add to our technical debt)?

This confused me for a while. If I've got it right, the restricted product is just prod_{i \in S} A_i x prod_{i notin S} R_i. Isn't the topology on this just "the product topology" rather than the "topology induced by the product topology on \prod_i R_i"? At least, mathematically? I'm not missing a subtlety here, am I?

You're right, I was influenced by my first approach (where I did the two-step construction in Lean), because it was easier to pullback the topology from \prod_i R_i rather than carry around the isomorphism with prod_{i \in S} A_i x prod_{i notin S} R_i. But indeed in the comment it's better to just say "the product topology".

I find "`x j ‚àà A j` eventually along `ùìï`" hard to understand, although it might be the way you think about it. Can you also mention (if I got it right) that this just means `{j : x j ‚àà A j} \in ùìï`? Then maybe us poor number theorists will find it easier to understand.

I think another good example to mention here would be the principal filter case (because it comes up in your description of the topology). Here it's just prod_{i \in S} A_i x prod_{i \not\in S} R_i, right? You mention it later but I think now is the best time.
If you're going to define cofinite at all, you should probably do it the first time you mention it rather than the third time.
(This is the problem of writing things in the wrong order...)
Do you think `comap` is a better name for this?
I don't really have an opinion. If you like `comap` better I can go with `comap`.
OK Yael has convinced me that this is OK
I am happy with `inclusion`
You made A have type `(i : Œπ) ‚Üí Set (R i)` globally in this file on line 110 so now we have got shadowed `A`s in our local context (and same for A'). This is a neat trick though.
I'll change name to avoid shadowing.

```suggestion
```
We already have one of these in this namespace.

```suggestion
properties when each `A i` is an open subset of `R i`. The key fact is that each
```
I thought all the cool kids did `obtain` nowadays (on the basis that it is a word, and `rcases` isn't).

That's an interesting remark. I think the main reason I like `rcases` better is that in the process of writing the proof, I first think "oh I should get something from this lemma" so I write `rcases lemma_name`, then look at the arguments of `lemma_name` to provide them, and only at the end I look at what it gives me precisely (and more importantly: in which order).
I agree with the workflow, except that it works just fine with `obtain`
This line is never used. In fact is it the case that there's just one result in the whole 750+-line file which uses R' and A' even though they're initialised globally?

This may be the case. I don't know what the policy is here, I know some people claim that you should always have your data at the section level and only shuffle hypotheses on the lemma level. But I agree this case is a bit extreme, so I'll remove the global `R'` and `A'`.

pullRequest.title: feat: restricted products and their topology
